column6: Reunion Island - land use map in 2022
column8: The TETIS research unit of CIRAD, within the framework of the "THEIA Cluster", is developing a land use mapping method based on the Moringa chain prototype which minimizes interactions with users by automating satellite image processing processes. The methodology jointly uses a Very High Spatial Resolution image (Spot6/7 or Pléiades) and one or more time series of High Spatial Resolution optical images (Sentinel-2 and Landsat-8) for a classification combining segmentation and object classification (use of the Random Forest algorithm) trained by a training database combining field collection and photo-interpretation. The land use maps are produced as part of the GABIR project (Agricultural Management of Biomass on the scale of Reunion Island) and are all referenced on the CIRAD dataverse (https://dataverse.cirad.fr) and disseminated on the CIRAD spatial data catalog (http://aware.cirad.fr).
column10: Cirad agricultural research for development
column11: Le Mézo, L., Dupuy, S., & Gaetano, R. (2023). Reunion - land use map in 2022 (V1) [Data set]. CIRAD Dataverse. https://doi.org/10.18167/DVN1/F0SUQC

column6: Mapping the Terrestrial Ecosystems of the Conterminous U.S.
column8: Ecosystem maps are foundational to spatially explicit ecosystem conservation planning  and management, environmental reviews, and other applications ranging from ecosystem  accounting to ecosystem education. For those reasons, we developed a 30m spatial resolution  map of the terrestrial ecosystems of the conterminous U.S. (CONUS) and adjacent areas in Mexico and Canada based on the latest version of the U.S. National Vegetation Classification  (USNVC), which provides a comprehensive, hierarchical, standard, authoritative ecosystem  classification well suited for use in ecosystem mapping. The map builds on a previous map of ecosystems that was developed in a collaboration between NatureServe, a conservation NGO, and LANDFIRE, an interagency wildland fire management spatial data program that is supported and managed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service Fire and Aviation Management and the U.S. Department of the Interior Office of Wildland Fire. The map  documents the USNVC group types, which are mid-level ecosystems of the 8-level USNVC hierarchy; 323 groups and eight additional land cover and anthropogenic land use categories are mapped across the entire map extent, with 308 groups present in CONUS. The USNVC v3.0 and NatureServe’s International Vegetation Classification (IVC) were recently aligned with the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Global Ecosystem Typology (GET) in support of global ecosystem assessments. The GET is the reference classification for the Group  on Earth Observation’s (GEO) Global Ecosystem Atlas (GEA) initiative; thus, we can aggregate the USNVC map units to the GET ecosystem types for use by GEA for the U.S. portion of the Atlas. The USNVC is suitable for this product because it is the national standard for vegetation classification adopted by the Federal Geographic Data Committee, is maintained through peer review by the Ecological Society of America’s Vegetation Classification Panel, and provides a standard for the 50 states and other programs in the NatureServe Network. As such, the v1.0  ecosystem map is recognized as an authoritative national dataset that reflects substantial advances over previous ecosystem maps for the U.S. It is available in the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0) license as a 30m ecosystems raster dataset and as a complete series of individual ecosystem range maps mapped at five spatial scales using NatureServe’s standard Nested Hexagon Framework
column10: NatureServe; USDA Forest Service; USGS

column6: Land use - Mayotte - 2023 map
column8:
We are releasing land use maps of the island of Mayotte produced in 2023 using a methodology combining machine learning and object-based satellite image analysis (OBIA). This work was carried out as part of the BIOTAMAYA project (OFB funding: French Office for Biodiversity). The maps are produced using the Moringa processing chain developed in our laboratory. We use a Pleiades image with very high spatial resolution (THRS), a time series of Sentinel-2 images, a digital height model (DHM) produced from stereoscopic Pleiades images, a digital terrain model (DTM) and a land use reference database.
The Pleiades image is used to generate an object layer using a segmentation algorithm. Each object is then classified using variables from the various data used. The hierarchical nomenclature chosen consists of 3 levels with a number of classes ranging from 10 to 33. We distribute, in vector format (shape), the most detailed map (level 3) which however contains, in the attribute table, the information of the other levels of the nomenclature. We also distribute in image format (raster) the maps corresponding to the 3 levels of the nomenclature.
The overall accuracy of the maps ranges from 94% to 90%.
A detailed report describing the data and methods used is available (see link below)
These data are freely accessible (CC-BY license) so that they can be used by land managers and researchers.
column10: UMR TETIS - AgroParisTech, Cirad, CNRS, INRAE
column11: Dupuy, Stéphane; Lelong, Camille; Gaetano, Raffaele; Villers, Alexandre. 2024. "Occupation du sol - Mayotte - Carte de 2023"

column6: A crop type dataset for consistentland cover classification in Central Asia
column8: Land cover is a key variable in the context of climate change. In particular, crop type information is essential to understand the spatial distribution of water usage and anticipate the risk of water scarcity and the consequent danger of food insecurity. This applies to arid regions such as the Aral Sea Basin (ASB), Central Asia, where agriculture relies heavily on irrigation. Here, remote sensing is valuable to map crop types, but its quality depends on consistent ground-truth data. Yet, in the ASB, such data are missing. Addressing this issue, we collected thousands of polygons on crop types, 97.7% of which in Uzbekistan and the remaining in Tajikistan. We collected 8,196 samples between 2015 and 2018, 213 in 2011 and 26 in 2008. Our data compile samples for 40 crop types and is dominated by “cotton” (40%) and “wheat”, (25%). These data were meticulously validated using expert knowledge and remote sensing data and relied on transferable, open-source workflows that will assure the consistency of future sampling campaigns.

column11: Remelgado, Ruben; Zaitov, Sherzod; Kenjabaev, Shavkat; Stulina, Galina; Sultanov, Murod; Ibrakhimov, Mirzakhayot; et al. (2020). A crop type dataset for consistent land cover classification in Central Asia. figshare. Dataset. https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.12047478.v2
